awd_titl_txt: HCC: Large: Social-Computational Support of Civic Engagement in Public Policymaking
awd_abstract_narration:
The overarching goals of this work are to understand and to provide socio-computational support for improving the entire cycle of technology-enabled civic engagement: (1) recruitment of people with a stake in the issues; (2) deliberative discussion in which they learn about the policy issues, engage with each other, voice questions and recount experiences; and (3) consensus building in which participants move toward collaborative content-creation, summarization of the knowledge that has emerged in discussion and the development of agreement around key points. In practice, efforts to use social media for citizen policy consultations often fell far short of their knowledge-generating and democracy-reinforcing goals. There thus is a crucial need to discover how to design civic engagement spaces that leverage the potential of social media, so that they support not simply more participation but rather better participation that will benefit both the policymakers seeking input and the citizens who participate in the discussion. 

To achieve this goal, the project integrates computer science research on natural language learning for social-computational systems, human-computer interaction research on online communities, social media design, and social science research on motivation and individual and group deliberative processes. The research will advance behavioral science understanding of the relationship between individual characteristics and successful e-deliberation; the communicative processes that characterize successful e-deliberation; and the group processes and moderator behaviors that promote a shift from open discussion to consensus building. It will advance the state-of-the-art in natural language processing by developing joint human-computer text analysis techniques to (1) promote on-line civic engagement in policy discussions and (2) facilitate deliberative moderation in this collaborative online setting. It will add to human-computer interaction by advancing recommender systems, online communities, and social media research to support mentoring activities and engagement with alternate points of view. Finally, it will extend scientific understanding of how to motivate and support broader, better citizen participation in public policymaking.

The work will have at least five broader impacts: (1) increase understanding of, and infrastructure for, e-participation in policy-making, and provide annotated datasets of civic deliberations for use by other researchers; (2) enhance education through graduate and undergraduate mentoring and development of a new interdisciplinary course on Online Civic Engagement; (3) promote STEM education diversity with programs for middle and high school girls; (4) provide community and government outreach activities; (5) benefit society by improved civic engagement in policymaking in general.

por.por_cntn:
Online platforms for civic engagement are intended to increase the efficacy and authenticity of public policymaking. In practice, however, efforts to use social media for citizen policy consultations often fall far short of their goals. The aim of this project was to understand how to design online civic engagement spaces, so that they support not simply more participation but also better participation. We aimed to understand and provide socio-computational support for the entire cycle of civic engagement: (a) stakeholder recruitment; (b) deliberative discussion; and (c) consensus building. To achieve this goal, the project integrated social science research on motivation and individual and group deliberative processes, computer science research on natural language learning for social-computational systems, and human computer interaction research on online communities and social media design.

The research built on Cornell's Regulation Room platform, which fosters productive discussion among stakeholders. We developed natural language processing techniques that helped identify the arguments present in a corpus of messages about a particular policy issue and evaluate the extent to which these propositions were supported.  We also conducted research in human-computer interaction that led to new user interfaces to Regulation Room that facilitate a thoughtful exchange of ideas.  Finally, we assessed our novel techniques and interfaces while the platform was being used for a number of real public discussions of policy issues.

Intellectual Merit: The research advanced social and behavioral science by increasing our understanding of how individual characteristics, communication processes, group behaviors and moderator behaviors help shape the success of online deliberation. The research advanced state-of-the art in natural language processing by developing novel human-computer text analysis techniques to promote online civic engagement in policy discussions and facilitate deliberative moderation and consensus-building. The work added to knowledge of human-computer interaction by providing novel interfaces to the deliberation system. Finally, the work extended legal and government understanding of how to motivate and support broader and more productive citizen participation in public policymaking.

Broader Impacts: The projected had a number of significant broader impacts. First, the Regulation Room platform was used for a number of real policy debates, which were improved by our techniques. Second, the components of the system were made freely available to other researchers and the general public through online software repositories. Third, we conducted a series of outreach activities in which we demonstrated our tools and techniques to the general public. Finally, the project provided educational impact through the mentorship of a large number of graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, undergraduate students, and professional master's students.
